awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Integrated Computational and Experimental (ICE) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) at North Carolina State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site led by Professors Elon A. Ison and Elena Jakubikova at North Carolina State University (NCSU). The primary focus of this REU site is to expose students from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) to one of many possible independent research topics that combine experimental techniques and computational methods.  At the same time, students are enabled to make more informed career and graduate or professional school choices. Upon program completion, students are better prepared to achieve a high level of success in their chosen pathways. Recruiting efforts include a series of strategies to recruit students from underrepresented groups, women, and first generation college students primarily in the Southeast and Middle Atlantic region, as well as from the University of Puerto Rico. 

Recent advances in computing have enabled computational methods to become an important tool for experimental groups, yet many undergraduates are not positioned to take advantage of this valuable resource. This site is designed to take advantage of the computational facilities at NCSU.  The students are engaged in projects that utilize computational methods to support, complement, and ultimately drive experimental research. Students are exposed to career opportunities in non-academic settings in the Research Triangle Park area. They also actively participate in social and professional activities provided on campus to encourage interactions with other undergraduates and REU programs at NCSU. In addition, there is component that involves the training of local high school teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates at the Interface of Computations and Experiments at the Department of Chemistry at North Carolina State University were: (1) to provide students from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), where opportunities for undergraduate research may be limited, with an opportunity to perform chemical research at a research-intensive university that seamlessly integrates experimental design and implementation with computational methods, (2) to assist students in career and academic decisions by broadening their perspectives on chemical research careers and 3) to provide students from underrepresented groups, women, and first generation college students with research opportunities and ultimately to increase the number of students from these groups in STEM fields. Twenty five students participated in the REU program in 2018-2021. Five students were from NCSU and were funded from the NCSU Chemistry Department and Lord Cooperation. The demographics for the program were: a) underrepresented groups: 36% b) PUIs (NSF funded): 96% c) women: 64% d) of students who have graduated, 88% pursued careers in STEM fields, 79% pursued PhDs in Chemistry or Biochemistry. In 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic, the program was held virtually with five PIs from NCSU and three non-NCSU PIs. Students presented posters at ACS National meetings, the annual NCSU Undergraduate Research symposium and presented research seminars to the Chemistry department.
